column4: Is there anyway to tell what parts of a jaunty upgrade may not be correct?  Since the upgrade, which didn't seem to finish completely, my system is messed up in a couple of key ways, like printing.
run the upgrade again
than it finished fine

Can't print from my system anymore, get communication errors, insert LiveCD, I can print.  Also, thunderbird (email client) was installed but didn't show up in package managers.  Reinstall caused some problems with config.
does sudo apt-get install -f? does sudo dpkg --configure -a help?
sudo dpkg --configure -a
installing th elist of packages that is said to be not needed does that install them?
the dpkg --configure -a command followed by apt-get install -f produced nothing new.
^^^ for youy
i need any and all info on the thunderbird part of this, the others are other peoples problems
and sudo apt-get -f install didnt help?
post your /etc/apt/sources.list file. pastebinit /etc/apt/sources.list
did you use update-manager or console?
i suggest removeing the conflcting packages than comment out the non official repos than try again (i hate that gutsy repo)
danbhfive:  lines 55 and down were things I re-enabled as per upgrade instructions: "some repos disabled, re-enable after upgrade"  Don't think I should have?
should not have
the upgrade process klnows what it is doing
so disable those repos again, and then what command(s) do I issue to get back to "release" versions?
without knowing the repo i cant say but i know what thunderbird depnds on and what rdepends are bu without knowing what is in repos i cant tell you
you have to remove the packages that it says are a problem than comment out the repos than install them again
look in synaptic or adept and look up those packages find the *ubuntu# versions
danbhfive:  Okay, trying that, thanks for the help!
